awd_titl_txt: Bridging Our Students to Their Future
awd_abstract_narration:
This S-STEM project provides scholarships and support to a diverse cohort of 32 low income Biomedical, Chemical and Environmental Engineering (BCEE) students at the University of Cincinnati's College of Engineering and Applied Science (CEAS) who pursue either a research preparation or an entrepreneurship focus.  The project aims to prepare a  diverse groups of students to excel in a rapidly changing, technology-driven world as future faculty, engineers, and technology managers in educational institutions, existing companies, as well as leaders in starting new, technology-based companies.  

This project offers BCEE S-STEM scholars four tracks: 1) a MS-ACCEND degree program, in which students earn both BS and MS degrees in engineering; 2) a new Graduate School Preparation track to prepare students earning a BS degree to enter MS and PhD programs; 3) a MBA-ACCEND program, in which students earn both BS and MBA degrees as well as a Graduate Certificate in Entrepreneurship; and 4) a new Professional Preparation track in which students earn a BS degree and a Minor in Entrepreneurship to prepare them for entrepreneurial activities after graduation.  The project implements four strategies to support and prepare its scholars: cohort building, career driven education, networking, and a defined pathway to graduate school.  An E-Portfolio tool, previously developed at the CEAS, is used to track student performance and participation and to identify students who need early intervention.  The tracks serve as models for programs seeking to incorporate research methods and discovery-based education to improve retention of students in dual-degree programs (BS-MS and BS-MBA), integrate research training into undergraduate engineering education, and streamline acquisition of the skills needed for technical and entrepreneurial innovation.

por.por_cntn:
Goal and Objectives

This S-STEM project was designed to address three challenges:

  • Anticipated increasing needs for engineers who can do research and engineer-entrepreneurs.
  • Some professional societies advocating for requiring MS degree for Professional Engineering licensure.
  • Low on-time completion rates for dual degree programs (BS+MS and BS+MBA) in the Biomedical Engineering (BME), Chemical Engineering (CHE), and Environmental Engineering (ENVE) programs at the University of Cincinnati (UC).

To address these challenges, the goal of this S-STEM proposal project was to produce BME, CHE and ENVE graduates from UC who would be among the first to be sought by the academy, industry and investors. To achieve this goal, four tracks, with appropriate student support systems, were developed:

  • A BS+MS degree program, in which students earn both BS and MS degrees in Engineering;
  • A Graduate School Preparation Track (GSPT) to prepare students earning a BS degree to enter MS and PhD programs;
  • A BS+MBA program in which students earn both BS and MBA degrees with a Graduate Certificate in Entrepreneurship; and
  • A Professional Preparation Track (PPT) in which students earn a BS degree and a Minor in Entrepreneurship to prepare for entrepreneurial activities after graduation.

Program Activities

Recruiting: 35 S-STEM Scholars (including 14 women and 8 minority students) were recruited in three Cohorts.  27 S-STEM scholars (including 8 women and 5 minority students) completed the program.  These students were distributed among majors and tracks as follows:

  • BME    BS+MS: 4; GSPT: 2; BS+MBA: 0; PPT: 2
  • CHE    BS+MS: 7; GSPT: 3; BS+MBA: 5; PPT: 1
  • ENVE  BS+MS: 2; GSPT: 0; BS+MBA: 1; PPT: 0

Academic Assessment and Monitoring: Several program activities were targeted at academic assessment and monitoring:

  • Scholars were assigned an S-STEM Mentor to complement their degree program advisor, and were required to meet with both their mentor and their degree program advisor once per semester. 
  • Scholars were required to obtain course progress reports from the instructor for each course taken. 
  • Scholars completed an annual reflective essay.

The outcomes from these activities were documented in an e-Portfolio.

Socials: Scholars attended monthly socials intended to better prepare them for the academic and professional worlds. 

Community Engagement: Scholars performed 15 hours/semester of volunteer service related to STEM education.

Cooperative Education: All UC Engineering students participate in Cooperative Education; Scholars followed work rotations developed with their co-op advisor.

Research Courses (BS+MS, GSPT Only): A CHE/ENVE research course sequence (Research Methods I, Research Methods II, and Undergraduate Research) was developed.  The Research Methods courses included a discipline-independent introduction to the scientific method, hypothesis generation, developing research plans, writing proposals and papers, and scientific presentations.

ePortfolio: An ePortfolio system was developed as a central data collection point for information from the Scholars.

Program Evaluation: Students documented each activity using ePortfolio forms.  End-of-Year surveys were used to evaluate satisfaction with program activities and program effectiveness. Scholars also completed a self-efficacy survey annually.  Research courses were also evaluated using surveys. Graduating seniors were asked to complete a final survey.  UC Evaluation Services collected and evaluated this data and reported results and improvement recommendations to the project team.

Outcomes and Recommendations

Retention: 77% of the Scholars recruited completed the program; all graduated with their BS degree.

Competencies Associated with College Persistence and Success: Annual Essays were scored against a rubric to assess academic self-efficacy, communication skills, persistence to continue in a STEM field, positive future self and growth mindset, sense of belonging to program and community, student approach, understanding of STEM as a career, and utility of courses.  Scholars scored significantly higher (p < 0.05) on this rubric in Years 2, 3, and 4 than in Year 1, as expected as the Scholars progress through their program.

Research Courses: S-STEM Scholars reported they could use the skills and apply the knowledge from the research courses. Responses to open-ended questions were consistent with the quantitative survey results.

Impact on Students: 88% of the Scholars agreed or strongly agreed the program improved their academic performance; 90% agreed or strongly agreed that it increased their confidence in their ability to succeed in engineering. All students evaluating the BS+MBA and BS+PPT tracks agreed that the S-STEM program increased their confidence in their ability to succeed in entrepreneurship activities.

Scholars reported the following major benefits and strengths of the program:

  • Building relationships with faculty and peers,
  • Creating opportunities for Scholars to better understand their fields,
  • Accessing financial aid,
  • Helping them stay on track for graduation/academic planning,
  • Networking, and
  • Providing individualized education. 

Scholars ranked the usefulness of program elements as follows (scores are means on a 4-point scale):

  • Mentorship (3.8)
  • S-STEM Courses (3.7)
  • Program Academic Advisor (3.5)
  • Community Engagement (3.4)
  • Monthly Socials (3.0)
  • Annual Reflective Essays (mean = 2.7)

It is recommended that the mentorship, specialized coursework, academic advising, community engagement, and monthly socials be included in programs modeled after the program developed in this project.


Last Modified: 10/25/2021
Modified by: Stephen W Thiel
